author: Sgt-Bullish
body:
I bought BGFV and ASO. Both did very well today. Already rocketed significantly but I thinks there’s a bit more gas in the tank. Same market. Different geographies.

A longer term play I like it Oracle. It’s ERP Netsuite is the standard for midsize companies. Oracle Cloud is a good ERP for large companies (I don’t think it has as much market saturation though). It’s database offerings, in addition, are essentially the only real alternatives to SQL Server. P/E is ~17. I bought that when they announced a dividend increase.

I have some others I’m less confident about. OI has a lot of debt that it seems to have managed (which in 2020 was not easy). LH and KT are both ones I have positions in. I think KT might turn into a long term play if it turns out to dominate the Korean market.

author: ThrowawayAl2018
body:
MongoDB is a niche product, the query language is convoluted if you ever had to use it. 

Still in negative earnings despite increased revenue, and going against the bigger boys (eg: Amazon, Microsoft, Oracle), it is an uphill climb. Question is when will the company run out of cash before you cash out with gains. 

Short term: look for bottom and sell on gain, current PE is still high despite the drop.

Long term: high risk, company spending a lot to win customer while competitors has deeper pockets and more established brand name.

author: No-Development-130
body:
This one is a patience stock, tis not gonna shoot up till it gets a large private vendor. while i like the Idea of getting involved with Governments i'm increasing thinking that Governments are going to be unable to fully move on from IBM and ORACLE systems in the short or medium term, and while PLTR can work with those systems I just don't see the full platform integration happing, which is what you need for those 22.00 to become 220.00 a share.   


I own PLTR and i'm down roughly 15%

author: tutoredstatue95
body: Keep in mind that Buffet uses very long dated European options for the most part. I don't believe he does anything like swing trading, but I could be wrong on that. He also lost around 2-4b on spy puts that he sold, can't remember the exact number but it's in a Berkshire letter to the shareholders.  Buffet's obviously one of the best, but his real skill is risk management and DD.  Going super bullish like that is not nornally a go to strategy, and it can definitely bite you in the ass even if you are an oracle.

author: RecommendationNo6304
body:
I agree the marketplace is a huge selling point. Here's a fast bear case.

2020 was an election year, and by all rights probably the biggest ad spend in history for online campaign money. The tailwind in earnings Facebook picked up from that cannot be understated. Assuming $10/share earnings is "the low end" for Facebook is the only way they end up at a 30 P/E, which is an implied 3% return, unless they grow significantly into the future.

I'm not convinced their meteoric rise in earnings is going to continue the next decade. Myspace was thought to be unstoppable at it's time in the limelight too, until it got face-checked into the history books. Maybe it's different this time, but these sorts of companies has a fragile side cheerleaders don't like to see. When they get unpopular, or something better comes along, the exodus can be very hard and fast.

Facebook has been surviving by buying out all challengers. If they can keep that up, great. Microsoft (sort of) did over the years, but they got hit with Antitrust all the same and some competitors found holes and ate their lunch too (Amazon Cloud, Oracle Database Lawyers (tm), Zoom, etc. etc.)

A lot of professionals I know won't touch Facebook (or Twitter, etc) simply because it's a bad career move. One mistake, unpopular opinion, bad remark after one too many cocktails, etc. can sink a career. It's just not worthwhile.

Some past monopolies (Bell/AT&T, Standard Oil are good examples) pulled a Terminator and re-morphed after being split up, because they had oligarchic qualities where each of the "babies" could sort of carve up a region and not compete with each other seriously. They waited it out and eventually just merged back into an oligarchy.

Facebook is the AT&T model, minus the regulation. Every user adds additional value to the system. Maybe it can be chopped up and survive, but it seems far-fetched to me. That's a very real risk.

As much hate as Microsoft got in the 90's, I would argue the disdain for monopoly is much more pronounced and organized today.

As for timing, Facebook is trading at all-time highs. I'm not sure "deeply undervalued" has a strong case, unless you are banking on $30/share earnings in 5-10 years from now.

author: Sgt-Bullish
body:
So I know people here my have other methodologies, but I try to follow the value investing approach of Graham and Dodd.

A lot of my portfolio is made up of positions I anticipate holding for a long time (BRK.B, STOR, AFL, ORCL to name a few) because there is an indication to me that the analysis I would perform each quarter would raise my price target (although I still should do the work to make sure).

Then there are the used cigarette butts I pick up for one last good puff. BGFV is one of these for me (OI, KT, VIAC are a few others). It’s probably got 10-15% upside in the next few months based on my research, and some probably have a bit of a longer period of upward momentum. But the plan is to sell once they hit a specific price (usually that margin is a minimum of 20% upside of the purchase). 

Any disciplined approach needs to have a goal for the specific position, aside from MPT (which is just garbage anyway) so long term holds need to be understood within the context of evaluating the investments future periodically. This is essentially the same thing someone who trades on price trends will tell you, it’s just that they work on must shorter time frames.

There are certainly alternative strategies, but I suspect people like Cathie Wood who buy on future promises will be as forgotten as the investors of the past who ignored things profitability and debt.
